description: Bamboozle! was a simple quiz game available through UK television broadcaster Channel 4's teletext service from 1993 to 2009. Hosted by Bamber Boozler and his family, the quiz consisted of between 12 to 25 multiple choice questions. Each question had four choices which the player selected using one of the four coloured buttons on their Fastext television remote, either red, green, yellow, or blue. To complete the quiz you have to answer all of the questions correctly. Originally if a player answered a question incorrectly they'd have to start the quiz again from the very beginning, however this was later changed so that the player would only have to re-answer a maximum of three questions.
title: Bamboozle!

description: Empire I is the first game in the Empire (PLATO) series. It was most likely the first networked multiplayer game available on an open network allowing more than two players. In this simulation game up to eight players take control of their respective planets. The screen showed each of the planets and space ships that the players controlled and information about the economy, population, manufacturing and trade. Space ships could be used to transport goods, attack and transport military forces.
title: Empire I

description: Empire II is a tactical shooting game where up to 50 players divided over 8 ships try to wrest control over the galaxy. The game changed the gameplay of its predecessor by allowing direct control of the spaceship and scrapping the economic simulation altogether. Unlike the single screen predecessor, part II features a game world of 8x8 sectors in which the players could fly around in a top down perspective. Starships followed the laws of physics keeping their momentum. To brake, the ship had to be rotated in reverse and thrust given to counteract the forces. Torpedoes were fired in the direction of movement.
title: Empire II

description: The third iteration of Empire maintained the core 50 player space shooter gameplay from Empire II but expanded on it in various ways while optimizing performance of the game. The player's ship now remained in the centre of the screen adding periodic scrolling. Space no longer wrapped around at the edges of the map so the map had strict borders. A mini-map shows the player's location in all of space. Ships still maintain their velocity and need to break by rotating it into reverse and thrusting in the opposite direction. Rotation is not instant and takes time. Ships can fire torpedoes and phasers to try to hit enemy ships.
title: Empire III

description: The -michelin- version of Empire was developed by a different developer and is inspired by Empire III which was unavailable at the time due to space being required for the development of Empire IV but made less complex. Players still control ships and try to shoot their enemies, but instead of a maximum of 50 players there are now 25, divided over 2 teams (Klingons and Federation) instead of 8. The control of the ships is simplified to allow more emphasis on team play. New features include the ability to orbit planets, tow objects and beaming a landing party.
title: Empire -michelin-

description:
The fourth official version of Empire integrates many of the simplifications and setting elements of Empire -michelin- although the story prompts were made optional. New is a strategic view which allows a more zoomed out view of the galaxy. Each player controls a starship which can destroy enemy starships, bomb enemy armies, beam up friendly armies and beam them down on enemy or neutral planets to capture them. The characteristics of the starships differ between races. Ships featured classic space ship weaponry such as phasers and torpedoes.

This version of the game has 4 teams (Federation, Romulans, Vulcans (later renamed Orions) and Klingons (later renamed Kazari)) and allows 32 players. Whichever team manages to conquer all 25 planets establishes an empire and wins the game. Occasionally in games a doomsday machine can appear. The only way to destroy it is by carefully timing a self-destruct.
title: Empire IV

description: Conquest is the spiritual successor of the first iteration of Empire. Where later Empire games removed the strategic management part and focused on space ship combat, Conquest is expanded on the source code of the original game and thus features planetary economy management. The screen showed each of the planets and space ships that the players controlled and information about the economy, population, manufacturing and trade. Space ships could be used to transport goods, attack and transport military forces. The game featured 4 parallel universes to allow more players to play.
title: Conquest

description: Air Race is credited with being the first 3D flight simulator game. Each player in this multiplayer game has a cockpit view of the horizon and must race each other.
title: Air Race

description: Airfight is a first person multi-player combat flight simulator. Its design is inspired by Air Race but added combat in the vein of Dogfight. The 3D view offers players a real-time view of the horizon airports and enemy aircraft. It served as an inspiration for the first Flight Simulator. At the bottom of the screen the instrument panel is shown with a radar and details such as heading, pitch, roll, altitude, fuel, etc.
title: Airfight

description:
Spacewar is a two player networked game inspired by the original Spacewar! on PLATO. Two players control a spaceship each in a two dimensional representation of space. The ships can thrust, rotate, and fire and must try to destroy each other. The ships are represented by custom ASCII graphics. Unlike the original Spacewar! Here ships have only limited fuel and hyperspace jumps. Connected users are listed on screen (big board) and can be challenged to a duel.

The game was originally written for PLATO III, but later ported to PLATO IV. When PLATO went on the ARPANET in 1974 the game became incompatible. It was replaced by Orbit War.
title: Spacewar

description:
Orbit War is a networked version of Spacewar! played through PLATO terminals over the ARPANET. It was written to replace the original 1969 implementation of Spacewar for PLATO that became incompatible after the switch to ARPANET.

Two players control a spaceship in a two dimensional representation of space. They can thrust, rotate and fire and must try to destroy each other.
title: Orbit War

description: Chess allows one or two players to play chess on a PLATO terminal. A game can be played against the computer (who takes random moves), or against another player on the same or another terminal.
title: Chess

description: Moonwar is a networked multiplayer shooting game. Players must try to hit their opponents on mountainous terrain with lasers. Players must guess angles and distances to make sure their shot hits their target. Shots can bounce off walls and hit obstacles in the terrain. Initially lasers would be absorbed when hitting the edges of the screen, but a later update changed them to deflect instead. The game uses a big board multiplayer matchmaking system where all current player names are shown on a big board and can challenge each other to a duel.
title: Moonwar

description: Dogfight is a networked multiplayer shooting game. In this 2D plane flying game players try to shoot each other out of the sky. The game features special effects by quickly invoking the slide projector in the terminal multiple times which makes the terminal light up and buzz and shake. Matchmaking was done using the big board system typical of PLATO multiplayer games, where people who logged in saw a screen with the names of everyone currently logged in and could challenge them.
title: Dogfight

description:
Spasim (pronounced Space Sim) is a networked 3D space combat game for up to 32 players. The game features four planetary systems and players fly around in spaceships. The game is presented in wireframe 3D with an update rate of roughly once every second. Each player can fire phasers and (manually guided) photon torpedoes and fight in teams (one for each planetary system). Players move their ship around by entering polar coordinates. To add an educational twist to the game (so that it would not be taken down from the PLATO network) positions are only available in Cartesian coordinates.

A later update added space stations and resource management and de-emphasized combat. Different teams can cooperate to extract valuable resources from far off planets. The proletariat on planets can also revolt.

The talkomatic chat system allows players to communicate with each other during the game.
title: Spasim

description: Backgammon is a networked version of the classic board game. The computer determines the outcome of dice rolls randomly as two players try to get their pawns across the board.
title: Backgammon

description: Backgammon is a networked version of the classic board game that also allows play against the computer. Players try to get their pawns across the board. The computer AI learns from games played and thus increases in skill over time.
title: Backgammon

description: Pedit5 or The Dungeon is a contender to being the first RPG computer game. The player explores a predefined dungeon of 40+ rooms in which random monsters wander that can be killed and treasure can be found. The dungeon is shown in a top down view and the player character and enemies are displayed as icons. In line with Dungeons & Dragons released a year earlier killing enemies yields experience points which make the player character level up and improve his statistics. There are different classes that can be played such as Mage and Cleric. The player uses keyboard shortcuts to attack, run, cast spells, etc. Navigation is done with the arrow keys.
title: The Dungeon

description: Bingo is an early implementation of the well known game for PLATO terminals. Players are rewarded virtual money based on bingo cards and randomly selected numbers.
title: Bingo

description:
Moria is an early first person RPG for multiple players. Development of the game was inspired by hearing stories of the development of contemporary dnd and Orthanc. As common in RPGs the player starts with creating a character. Characters have stats (Cunning, Piety, Valor, Wizardry, Vitality, Age) that determine the character's strengths and weaknesses. Characters move around the game world in a first person view with wire-frame graphics and movement in steps. Monsters can be fought with weapons and spells.

Food and water must be managed to stay alive and characters can also die of old age. The town area allows players to access shops and guilds (each of which had a special power for its members). The wilderness outside town features only weak monsters, but has entrances to four dungeons (Cave, Mountain, Forest, Desert) of 60 levels each. A hidden Ocean dungeon was added in a later update. Each level is on a 6x6 grid. Players can tie strings to objects to find their way back to previous locations, unless monsters chew it through. Magic objects can be found, but they are protected by boss monsters.

Players could create groups of up to 10 players to travel together under the lead of a designated guide.
title: Moria

description: Checkers allows two players to play the classic board game on a single PLATO terminal. It is also possible to play against the computer.
title: Checkers

description:
Panther is a tank combat simulation game for multiple players played over the PLATO network. The game uses a first person perspective with wireframe graphics later popularized by Battlezone. In the corner of their screen, the tank is shown in a top down view so that the rotation of the turret can be properly judged. Each player controls a tank and is part of one of two teams. Each team has a headquarters that must be destroyed by the other team. Each tank can be destroyed in a single shot and players cannot respawn. Tanks also have limited fuel and can carry mines.

The map is randomly generated, although it always has the same features and distances between the two bases. Players have access to a 2D map showing geographic features. Team mates can communicate with each other using text chat.
title: Panther

description:
Nova is a space exploration game played over the PLATO network. Players can cruise around the galaxy and visit different solar systems. The player beholds the galaxy from a space ship in a first person perspective.

It is played in real time, with real physics. Ships are entire ringworlds, with Bussard ramjets replacing the central sun. The galaxy is populated by stars using a pseudo-random number generator, which operates on a real galactic density function from the astrophysical literature. So stars doesn't move and can be revisited.

"stargen", the lesson space (program) that creates the stars, uses the same galactic density function to create a population of stars representing the types most likely to be found at that position. It uses a fourth-order Runge-Kutte integration in energy shells. The planet generator uses the elements found in the generated star to come up with a likely planetary system. Planets farther away from the sun will have atmospheric gasses which does not add up to 100% because some of the gasses will have frozen out on the planetary surface.

The game was never fully completed because a) you needed a battle computer to actually have a battle, and b) five running instances of the battle computer were too much for CDC 7600 mainframe it was played on.
title: Nova

description: Dungeon is a role playing game that runs on the PLATO network. Multiple players can join each other to explore the maze-like dungeon in a first person perspective to fight monsters. The game is considered one of the first Multi User Dungeon (MUD) games.
title: Dungeon

description: Go allows two players to play the ancient board game Go on a PLATO Terminal. Players take turns to place stones on a board and must try to surround and capture each other.
title: Go

description: Blackjack allows players to play the classic card game on the PLATO network against the computer. The player can choose to hit or fold and must try to get a score as close to 21 as possible but cannot get over or be busted. The goal is to win as much virtual money as possible.
title: Blackjack

description: Bridge allows players on four different terminals to play a game of Bridge. The game features an introduction to the game as well as point-count bidding. The computer deals the cards and checks the validity of plays, but cannot play the game itself.
title: Bridge

description: Contract is a contract bridge game on the PLATO network. Players can play in teams over multiple terminals or play against the computer.
title: Contract

description: Tic Tac Toe allows the classic game to be played over the PLATO network.
title: Tic Tac Toe

description: This version of Tic Tac Toe on the PLATO network allows a player to play against the computer. The computer has five different intelligence levels and adjusts based on the skill of the player.
title: Tic Tac Toe

description: 4-D Tic Tac Toe allows players to play the classic game of Tic Tac Toe but in four dimensions. Whoever gets three in a row first wins.
title: 4-D Tic Tac Toe

description: Add-to-13 Solitaire is a solitaire card game also known as Pyramid Solitaire. Cards are placed in a pyramid shape of seven overlapping layers. The goal is to get all cards to the foundation. But cards can only be moved there in pairs when they add up to a value of 13. Cards in the stock can be turned if no moves are available. A turned card can be used to make a match, but if there is no valid move it's moved to the foundation regardless.
title: Add-to-13 Solitaire

description: Four Suit Stack Solitaire is a solitaire card game. The cards are dealt in four rows of 13 cards and the player must move cards to form piles of sorted suits in ascending order.
title: Four Suit Stack Solitaire

description: Moonbattle is a two player game in which players are tested in their arithmetic knowledge. Both players must try to hit each other with an artillery. It is a version of Moonwar with an educational twist.
title: Moonbattle

description: The Perfect PLATO Poker Parlor allows players to play the card game Poker over the PLATO network.
title: Perfect PLATO Poker Parlor

description: Yahtzee is an implementation of the classic dice game for the PLATO network. Players roll dice and try to make straights, full house, x of a kind etc. while re-rolling a limited number of times.
title: Yahtzee

description: Racetrack is a computerized version of the 1960s pen and paper game of the same name. The game simulates a car race for multiple players. Each player starts their car by selecting a grid point adjacent to the point on the grid the car is currently located. After this during each turn the car can be moved in the same direction and the same number of squares, or any of the squares adjacent to that changing the velocity vector for subsequent turns. Cars musn't crash into the boundaries, which requires the players to make sure to brake in time for sharp turns.
title: Racetrack

description: Race is a horse race betting game on the PLATO network. The player receives $1000 in virtual currency and places bets with a limit of fifteen races.
title: Race

description: The Hop Game is an educational title for two children played over the PLATO network. Players take the role of either a bunny or a frog and hop over a game board using a spinner.
title: The Hop Game

description: Slot Machine simulates a "one armed bandit". The player can spin the wheels in order to raise the stakes.
title: Slot Machine

description: Solitaire Dice is a dice game for a single player. It's played on a PLATO terminal. It's based on the dice game of the same name by Sid Sackson that appeared in the book A Gamut of Games.
title: Solitaire Dice

description: Concentration is a typical visual memory game played on a PLATO terminal. The player must select tiles to reveal them with the aim of finding two identical ones. Tiles are turned back so the player must remember where specific tiles are.
title: Concentration

description:
Orthanc is an RPG on the PLATO network. It draws heavily from Pedit5 but has larger dungeons, more monsters, spells, etc. The player takes on the role of a knight with the goal of retiring as a proven warrior. The knight has various statistics (strength, intelligence, constitution and dexterity) which have an effect on the actions taken in the game. The game is shown in a top down perspective with statistics, experience, spells and inventory shown at the bottom half. To get experience points the player needs to exit the dungeon and convert the accumulated treasure. Levelling up gives access to more spell units (required to cast spells) and hit points.

The game features an automap (added in a later update, 25 years on) and the player can encounter other players in the dungeon and can chat or fight with each other.
title: Orthanc

description: Hangman is a word guessing game. The player must guess letters. Each incorrectly guessed letter makes part of a hangman drawing appear. The player must guess the word before the drawing is completed.
title: Hangman

description: Perquacky is a word creation game on PLATO based on the dice game Perquackey. The player gets a set of random letters and must make words with the given letters within the time limit.
title: Perquacky

description: Panzer is a tank simulation game for PLATO created for the US Army Armor School at Fort Knox. The game is played from a first person perspective with wireframe graphics and simulates armored warfare for multiple players. It bears similarities with Panther but has much more detail to make it more valuable for actual training. When firing players must take into account the velocity of their own tank, the target and even the curvature of the earth.
title: Panzer

description: Scrabble is an unofficial port of the classic board game for the PLATO network. Players take turns to create words on a board using tiles with letters. New words must connect the words already on the board. Different letters give different values and some locations on the board give multipliers for letters or words. Whoever has the most points wins the game.
title: Scrabble

description: Magic Squares is a sliding puzzle for PLATO with 15 numbered tiles which must be shifted into the correct position in as little time as possible.
title: Magic Squares

description: In Maze for the PLATO network, the player must find the exit of a randomly generated complex maze.
title: Maze

description: Mazewar (not to be confused with Maze War) is a maze game for multiple players over the PLATO network. Players must try to move their character from their home box to the opponent's home box, before the opponent does the same.
title: Mazewar

description: In Minefield the player must manoeuvre a submarine through a minefield with the goal of reaching the other side unharmed. The game is played on a PLATO terminal.
title: Minefield

description: Sharp is a puzzle game played on a PLATO terminal in which tiles of various sizes must be moved to get a desired piece to the bottom. All tiles are placed in a square field and must remain within the field. The goal is to get the correct tile at the bottom in the least possible moves.
title: Sharp

description: Guesser is a number guessing game played on a PLATO terminal. The player must guess a number of four digits based on provided hints and logical reasoning. The game features six different difficulty levels.
title: Guesser

description: Jeopardy is an unofficial conversion of the TV Show Jeopardy! for the PLATO terminal. In this reverse quiz, the player must formulate a question for a given answer to score points.
title: Jeopardy

description: Race Tangle is a game similar to the PLATO game Racetrack. The game simulates a car race for multiple players. Each player starts their car by selecting a grid point adjacent to the point on the grid the car is currently located. After this during each turn the car can be moved in the same direction and the same number of squares, or any of the squares adjacent to that changing the velocity vector for subsequent turns. Cars musn't crash into the boundaries, which requires the players to make sure to brake in time for sharp turns. The biggest difference with Racetrack is the complexity of the tracks.
title: Race Tangle

description: Regatta is a boat racing game. Four players play on a single PLATO terminal and race their boat along three numbered buoys in numerical order. The first who crosses the finish line wins the race.
title: Regatta

description: Diplomacy is an unofficial implementation of the classic war game / board game. The game pits different national forces against each other in a diplomatic game of war from the perspective of a world map.
title: Diplomacy

description: Antisubmarine Warfare Exercise is an educational target shooting game played on a Plato terminal. In the game the player must drop depth charges with the aim of taking out an enemy submarine.
title: Antisubmarine Warfare Exercise

description: Bombing Run is a simulation of bombing played on a Plato terminal. The player must try to hit its target taking rate of climb or descent, height and speed into account.
title: Bombing Run

description: Fishwar is a multiplayer shooter played over the PLATO network. Players can start a game from the big board, where other waiting players are visible. Players can join teams.
title: Fishwar

description: Foxhunt is a two-player game in which both players try to shoot a fox. The player who either shoots the fox or the other player wins the game.
title: Foxhunt

description: Rifle Range is a target shooting game played on a PLATO terminal. The goal for the player is to fire at targets in the distance. The gun sight needs to be adjusted to make proper allowance for wind drifts.
title: Rifle Range

description: Subwar is a single terminal PLATO game in which players either control a nuclear submarine or battleship and fight each other. The game area consists of land and sea areas.
title: Subwar

description: Targon is a target shooting game played on a PLATO terminal. The player must try to hit moving targets.
title: Targon

description: In Turkey Shoot the player controls three pilgrims. The goal of the game is to shoot a computer-controlled turkey.
title: Turkey Shoot

description: Baseball is a simulation of a game of baseball played on a PLATO terminal. The player controls the PLATOIANS and can play against four real-life teams.
title: Baseball

description: Bus Line is a traffic network simulation game. The player is in charge of public transit by bus in Platoland and is charged with running and planning the bus system in addition to dispatching buses for a "dial-a-bus" system.
title: Bus Line

description: Picto is a programming language for elementary school children on the PLATO network. The Picto lesson space contains three simple programming games to help the children get started.
title: Picto (included games)

description: Ping Pong is a table tennis simulation played on a PLATO terminal.
title: Ping Pong

description: Stocks and Bonds is an implementation of the 1964 board game by 3M for the PLATO terminal. Each round in the game represents a year, in which the players must buy and sell stock. The aim of the game is to become the wealthiest player.
title: Stocks and Bonds

description:
Dungeon, often remembered under the title m199h was one of the first computer role playing games. It was available on the PLATO network, the name m199h deriving from the foreign language lesson space the game was hiding until it was deleted from the network by moderators. Consequently little details about the game survive to this day.

The game bore striking similarities to dnd and featured advanced character sets serving as graphics for the monsters in the game, including a flying dragon picture. Unlike later RPGs on the PLATO network it was a single player game.

Based on surviving resources, it is believed Dungeon was a remake of the earlier game The Dungeon (aka Pedit5). A single player would enter a dungeon and fight monsters, cast spells, and collect treasure. The game stated it would implement all spells from the pen and paper Dungeons & Dragons: Greyhawk supplement, but it is unknown whether all these spells were implemented before the game was removed from the server. The game featured teleporters and chest traps which were new compared to Pedit5, but lacked a backstory.
title: Dungeon

description: Darts is an educational game that tries to teach fractions to young children. It's played on a PLATO Terminal. The player is presented by a vertical timeline, with various differently-shaped balloons displayed along the side. When prompted to hit one with a dart the player must enter the location of the balloon, either in fractions or decimals or a sum of either.
title: Darts

description: Torpedo is an educational game in which the player controls a submarine. On the ocean's surface ships appear which need to be shot. Fish and other marine animals swimming in the sea can block the shot. The submarine is moved back and forth by entering an amount to move. Negative numbers move the submarine back and positive move it forward. To reach the correct locations fractions need to be used. It can be played against the computer or with two players.
title: Torpedo

description: Wordwar is a multiplayer spelling game played over the PLATO network. Players compete with each other to type words correctly the fastest. The game allows play in multiple languages.
title: Wordwar

description: MegaWars is version of DECWAR for CompuServe. It plays similar to DECWAR, but has all references to Star Trek removed. It features new scenarios, strategies and planetary economic systems. The game ran almost continuously until 1998. In 1986 the game was released on GEnie as Stellar Warrior where it ran until 1999.
title: MegaWars

description:
MegaWars III is an advanced sequel to MegaWars released on CompuServe. Part II was meant to be a major update for the original game, but was never released in favour for this more advanced game.

MegaWars III is to be considered an expanded version of the game S. Up to 100 players engage in ship to ship combat and explore the galaxy with a simple planetary economic system for a 1000 planets. A single game would generally take over a month to complete. The game was also released for GEnie as Stellar Emperor with some minor adjustments such as the removal of ship customization.
title: MegaWars III

description:
S is a real-time multiplayer space combat game for up to 8 players. It is played over a network and hosted by a HP-2000F mainframe at the University of Virginia. The game is written in BASIC and draws inspiration from Star Trek games popular in the early 70s. Players control a spaceship and fly around the galaxy filled with 255 star systems. Players can conquer planets which have a simple economics system and engage in ship-to-ship combat.

The game served as an inspiration for the game MegaWars III.
title: S

description: Futurewar is a first person shooter game on the PLATO network. Players walk around in a maze-like first person environment with a gun right in front of them. Monsters can be found in the maze which need to be shot, as well as other players. There are different types of hazardous terrain such as fire, water, and radioactive waste. Elevators allow players to change levels. The bottommost level is called Hell and features the devil himself as a monster.

sample_screenshots.caption: Combat with a robot in Futurewar.

title: Futurewar

description:
Avatar is a multi player first person role playing game on the PLATO network. It aspired to be bigger and better than any of its predecessors such as Pedit5, DND, Moria, Oubliette and Futurewar.

In typical RPG fashion, players roll a character and can try to gain power by increasing their level through experience points and acquiring (magic) items. The game supports 60 simultaneous users and allows for in-game messaging with a system that features global, group and personal messages. Players can form groups to start exploring the game world. Some spells allow the leader of a group to teleport the entire group. Teleportation could lead to the player (or a whole group) being stoned (inside rock) as in Oubliette. Only an operator could undo the effects.

The game borrows the boss monsters concept from DND such as "Reaper of Souls"
title: Avatar

description:
Life is an implementation of Conway's Game of Life on PLATO. The player can draw patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
title: Life

description:
Drygulch is a MUD game taking place in a Western setting. Inspiration for the name comes from How the West was One + Three x Four where Dry Gulch is one of the train stops. Instead of exploring a fantasy dungeon as was the standard at the time in Drygulch the player explores a gold mine. The player can visit the town itself where there are various locations such as the town hall, bank, general store, assay office (where gathered ore can be turned into money), Kitty's Saloon, the sheriff's office and jail, a stable, a hotel, and the cemetery Boot Hill. Each locale has its own contextual menus allowing for different interactions. Not all of which might necessarily help the player, such as shooting the assay office's proprietor. Actions can lead the player to prison or the cemetery. Elections allow players to run for mayor, sheriff and inspector, bringing even more options to play. The Sheriff can assign rewards to the capture of other players that broke the law and send them to jail. Elected players can be killed even when they are offline.

The core of the game uses a typical stats system similar to Dungeons and Dragons, with stats like strength and dexterity. But it also added stats for injuries, hunger and thirst and carrying capacity. Players can buy a mule at the stables which has similar stats. Instead of fantasy monsters the mine features rats, bats, spiders, bears and coyotes. When coming in contact with a creature a player has the choice to fight, swear (scare it away), ignore (hope it will do the same), evade (skill check based on dexterity) or run. A random roll would determine the outcome of the player's actions.

The dungeon is displayed in a first person view with vector graphics showing walls. The town locales are 2D graphical depictions.
title: Drygulch

description: Fractions Basketball is an education game on PLATO that tries to teach fractions to children through a game of basketball. The player must accurately gage the distance between the ball and the hoop to make it score.
title: Fractions Basketball

description: Can-Am is a multiplayer text-based simulation of the Canadian-American Challenge Cup written in BASIC. One player hosts a game and other players join using link/join keywords. Each turn the computer will describe the situation and ask the player to input a desired speed up to 200 mph. The player can also drift behind opponents (which automatically mimics their speed). If the player's choices get out of hand, they may result in a crash and death.
title: Can-Am

description: Build-Up is a three dimensional maze game running on PLATO based on a story by James Graham Ballard. Unlike most mazes this game also features passages going up and down.
title: Build-Up

description: Simsex or Simulated Stock Exchange is a educational game in which players can buy and sell stock at a simulated market. Each player starts with an amount of cash and can trade freely in stock of existing companies. The values used are actual values from the real stock exchange. Aside from buying and selling players can also engage in other features of the stock market such as selling short, trading on margin, investing in savings accounts, earn dividends, receive stock splits and dividends. Transactions also incur commissions to brokers. Users can use an audit program to perform actions and another program to poll all the activities of the day for all players playing on the mainframe.
title: Simsex

description: Swords and Sorcery is a Star Trek variant in a fantasy setting and is in turn based on Think15. The game became available on the PLATO network in 1977 and was updated until 1979. Instead of the Enterprise the player controls a hero. The game retains the game world of a 10x10 universe with each quadrant consisting of 10x10 tiles. Hiding in the tiles the player can find all kinds of threats such as wizards, demons, werewolves, goblins, zombies and a dragon. The player can go to the castle to receive a mission (e.g. kill a number of enemies of type x) and earns experience points for various actions in the game. The player also accumulates gold and collect different weapons and equipment. Magic items were added in spring 1978. Players can also chop down trees. The game does not feature player interaction, but there is a spectator mode.
title: Swords and Sorcery

description: Think15 is a Star Trek variant in a fantasy setting. It was swiftly removed from the PLATO network, but found a more successful successor in Swords and Sorcery. The game combines elements from Dungeons & Dragons with the Star Trek video game popular in the 70s. The player must explore a grid-based world in order to hunt enemies and kill them without getting killed.
title: Think15

alternate_titles.description: From the title screen of version 8 for the PLATO system.
alternate_titles.title: The Game of Dungeons

description:
dnd, or The Game of Dungeons, is a terminal-access CRPG originally hosted on the PLATO network, and as of 2004 has been hosted on the Cyber1 network in an emulated form. Like pedit5, developed either before it or concurrently with, it is a pure dungeon crawler, heavily inspired by the Dungeons & Dragons roleplaying game published only a year before it.

You generate a character with randomly chosen stats including Strength, IQ, Wisdom, Dexterity, and HP, which are initially each set between 3 and 18, but can increase or decrease based on events in the game. Your goal is to explore a 20-level dungeon, find gold (which increases your HP and spell points), gain XP to gain more character levels, find magic equipment, and eventually become strong enough to kill a dragon on the lower floors of the dungeon, take its magical orb, and survive the trip back to the surface as the orb gathers the attention of extremely strong monsters.

Encounters with monsters may be resolved by fighting, escaping, or casting spells. Your spell stock is limited, but is often the best way to kill monsters without suffering damage in a straight fight. Gold is found everywhere, lying in piles around the dungeon, and the deeper you venture, the bigger the piles, but the more gold you carry, the stronger the monsters that you will attract. Even bigger piles of gold may be found in randomly found treasure chests, but chests are sometimes trapped, and opportunities to detect or disarm traps are limited.

Beware, for the death of your character is final, and there is no way to recover except by starting from the beginning again.

The original 1975 version by Ray Wood and Gary Whisenhunt no longer exists, but the Cyber1 network hosts v5.4 and v8.0 versions of the game, both featuring enhancements made by Dirk and Flint Pellett. The v8.0 version is much bigger and much more complex, featuring three dungeons instead of one, and an online instruction manual with more than twice as many pages.

sample_screenshots.caption: Clerically examining a magic item and finding it "harmless" is one of the best things that can happen in this game.
Attribute rolls are generous during character creation.

title: dnd

description: Hobbits and Orcs is an educational problem solving game in which the player must solve a puzzle where the player must ferry orcs and hobbits across a river without the orcs ever outnumbering the hobbits on either side of the river. This implementation of the classic problem is on the PLATO network.
title: Hobbits and Orcs

description:
Basketball is a simulation of the popular sport on PLATO. In this game however the player has some input. There are two variants, one for NBA and one for NCAA Basketball. The game shows a line drawing of a basketball court. At less than one frame per second the player can instruct the players on the field represented by numbers. Available actions include move, shoot, press, block and steal. Players gain fatigue during the course of the match

The game was preceded by an earlier entertainment title by the same developers, a baseball simulation similar to BBC Vik: The Baseball Demonstrator, which did not involve any input from the player but rather played out a randomly generated match.
title: Basketball

description: NFL is a football simulation game on the PLATO network. The players take on the role of the coach. The screen is divided in multiple segments, showing the play field, the scrum, player stats and game stats. As a coach the player gives plays and sees the action unfold.
title: NFL

description:
PLATO Flats is a golfing simulation on the PLATO network. The game features various terrain types such as sand and water hazards, rough, fairway, putting greens, trees, etc. The game uses a top down view to display the course with various zoom levels, but the player enters their shot information using a text prompt. For each turn the player must pick a club and adjust aim based on wind velocity and direction as well as give a power level for the swing. Direction is entered as an angle, where right = 0 degrees, up=90 degrees, left = 180 degrees and down = 270 degrees, which takes some getting used to. After each shot the graphics update once to show the new location of the ball and you repeat the process. The game allows play with multiple players over the network. Also included is a driving range for practising hitting the ball.

The game was eventually removed from the PLATO network and recreated from scratch as "Golf".

sample_screenshots.caption: Welcome to the CYBIS Flats Country Club (CYBIS is the name of a PLATO Service)

title: PLATO Flats

description: Bugs 'N Drugs is a typical dungeon crawling RPG game with an a-typical setting. inspired by DND, but instead of a dark dungeon the game takes place in a hospital. The player controls a character through a top down maze-like environment and must fight enemies which come in the form of germs and bacteria. To kill them the player must apply the correct antibiotics.
title: Bugs 'N Drugs

description:
Multi-User Dungeon: MUD1 or simply MUD is an online game where multiple players can simultaneously explore a dungeon using a text-based interface. When logging in to the game the player starts with creating a character, which consists of a name and sex. The aim of the game is to become a wizard or witch. To become a wizard a player must accumulate 102,400 points from the accumulation of treasure (and then dumping it in the swamp) and killing other creatures or players. Once the player becomes a wizard he or she becomes a game operator with additional powers including immortality.

The world is described through text snippets and the player is encouraged to maintain a map using pen and paper. To move around the game uses a text parser similar to early text adventures. Additionally the player can look around and interact with various objects and characters. Since the game allows many people to be connected at once textual chatting is a large part of the experience.

Characters have a stamina, strength and dexterity statistic which used for fighting. Dexterity is the chance of striking the enemy, strength determines the amount of damage done and stamina the amount of damage that can be had before dying. Fleeing from a fight loses the player points, and the victor wins points. When dying in a fight the player has to start over completely. Stamina regenerates when using the sleep command or when not playing the game. The statistics are increased by increasing the player level which is based on the current score of the player.

There are two different deaths in the game. Dying in a fight (stamina drops to 0) results in a permanent death. Other events such as traps or jumping of a cliff results in a temporary death. The player is booted from the game and all items are dropped. They must be recovered manually.
title: Multi-User Dungeon: MUD1

description: Freecell on the PLATO mainframes is the first implementation of the solitaire card games later made famous by being included with various editions of Microsoft Windows. The goal is to move cards around according to specific rules including the use of "free cells" in which cards can be placed temporarily, until all cards on the board are sorted in stack ordered by suit and number. The game would keep a high score list on the network allowing for players to compete.
title: Freecell

description: The Pits of Baradur is a dungeon crawling RPG on the PLATO network. Its name takes inspiration from The Lord of the Rings. Gameplay-wise the game takes elements from other dungeon crawling games on Plato such as Orthanc, Moria and Avatar placing the player in dungeons to find loot and kill monsters.
title: The Pits of Baradur

description:
Worms for Sky Digital is a simple adaptation of the iTV version of Worms series for the Sky Gamestar, as a game available in the UK, with unchanged premise. Therefore, two players have their teams with Worms and they fight until one of the team is destroyed. The cost of game was 50p.

The game, alongside the Sky Gamestar service, was shut down in 2006.
title: Worms for Sky Digital

description:
DND1 is the first CRPG created by Richard Garriott, and the first in a line of development that eventually resulted in Akalabeth: World of Doom and Ultima. It was originally coded in BASIC on a PDP 11, and played over a teletype, with the display printed onto paper. The original version can't be played now as it was never released commercially, but in 2014 Garriott unearthed the code, and ran a competition where the goal was to recreate the game so that it would be playable in a browser. Several of the versions created are still online, and the game is also playable within Garriott's Shroud of the Avatar.

The gameplay is heavily based on the tabletop RPG Dungeons & Dragons. You randomly generate a character with scores in Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma, purchase equipment, and choose one of three classes (Fighter, Cleric or Wizard). Then you enter a top-down dungeon represented by ASCII characters, where you fight monsters and collect treasure. There's no story, and no goal beyond amassing treasure, which you can use to buy more hit points as well as spells.
title: Dungeons and Dragons #1

description: Adventure is a text-adventure game that ran on the PLATO network. It is written from scratch, but incorporates rooms from both the original Mainframe Adventure and Zork, joined with new content. The player explores various locations and the way they are connecting to each other is completely different from the games it's based on. Also the puzzles and location of items is different.
title: Adventure

description: Mah-Jongg is the very first computer implementation of the solitaire variant of Mahjongg, also known as Shanghai. It was created for the PLATO computer system with an orange and black display. Normal Mahjongg tiles are stacked on a specifically shaped pile called a turtle and the player must match two identical tiles to be able to remove them, but the tiles must be free to take (e.g. not support other tiles on top of them). The goal is to clear the entire board of tiles. The height of tiles was shown by increasing the border thickness, so tiles that were higher up the stack would have a thicker border.
title: Mah-Jongg

description:
Camelot is a multiplayer RPG game that runs on the PLATO network. Players control a knight of the round table in Arthurian times. King Arthur is sick and only the Holy Grail can save him. This is the players' primary quest. The player can choose from different character types to play (human, dwarf, elf, hobbit, ogre, pixie), each has their own different stats which are mostly taken directly from DND (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Charisma, Armor Class), which allow for different play styles.

The game uses a first person perspective with a wire-frame view of the world, showing players where they can go. The player starts in the city but enters the dungeons beneath where most of the action takes place. Different actions such as killing monsters or stealing items from them awards score which is accumulated until the character dies or retires. The title screen of the game shows the leaderboard of the characters who reached the highest score.

Combat uses attack and defense stats which are modified by the player's level and other stats. The player can make combat easier by trying to charm a monster they encounter. If the charm is successful the monster will join them as a companion until the effects wear off. During their quest players can also find various items and gold to help them on their way. Items can be bought and sold in a store in the city.

The game features four different difficulty modes.

A later addition of the game was auto-mapping, which allows a player to log in with a different account to a different program which shows a top-down map of the dungeon and the current location of one or more players. Any traps and secrets are not shown on the map.
title: Camelot

description: Desert Rat! is a game based on the WWII North African battles between the Axis and Allied forces. Two players play against each other, one taking the role of general Montgomery, the other the role of General Rommel in a tank battle. The game is played over the Prestel service that sends information via phone line and displays the visual part of the game on the players TV screen.
title: Desert Rat!

description: Obliterate! is a simple multiple choice game where the player is in charge of a submarine taking aim at a battleship through a periscope. The game was released via the Prestel viewdata service, and had generic theming before being updated the following year to one inspired by the Falklands War. In the game, the player must first select the estimated range from the submarine to the battleship (with a choice of 10 options from 1000 yards to 10000 yards), then select the time it takes for the submarine's "thermodynatronic" torpedos to detonate. If the player selects the right combination of these two options, the ship is successfully destroyed. If not, the player must try again.
title: Obliterate!
